												4 Elements is a fun match-3 puzzler weighed down by unnecessary seek-and-find sequences and occasionally frustrating level design. 4 Elements' generic fantasy presentation hides an addictive game that will appeal to fans of Bejeweled and other "casual" puzzle titles. There's nothing wrong with story in a puzzle game, but with the relatively low resolution of the somewhat blurry art in the seek-and-find sequences, gamers will want the title to get out of its own way and let the real game breathe.4 Elements tells a simple story of an ancient evil that was locked away by the power of the titular elements — earth, wind, fire and water — but has now been unleashed. It's up to the player to unlock four books to release the elements and save the realm. It's inoffensive and flat, but the story is bolstered by a fairy who accompanies the player and periodically provides tips and hints. Unlike some other games that have overused the "helper" character while not allowing the player to discover and explore, the fairy is here to explain the various rules and power-ups and won't get in your way.The main gameplay of 4 Elements involves creating chains of three or more jewels of the same colour to clear a pathway for a liquid to reach the tree at the end of each level. The 64 timed levels are large and sprawling, with multiple pathways and strategies for the player to take. There are 16 levels per "element," and the colours and visuals change depending on which element you're playing, adding a bit of variety to the proceedings while playing; as you progress, the levels become harder, longer and with more obstacles. For example, you might stumble upon a stone that can only be destroyed via a bomb power-up, or a frozen tile that must be chained several times before breaking.There are environmental tricks, as well, with arrows that help clear large sections of the level when the liquid reaches them. There are several power-ups, such as the aforementioned bomb, the ability to swap any two regular jewels, "dig" out a tile to make way for another, and a power-up that reshuffles all jewels in the level besides stones and frozen tiles. Some jewels sit on more than one layer and must be cleared several times, as well. The time limit is rarely going to make players nervous, but it does add a good bit of tension as players scramble to reach the tree after a long journey.Supplementing the main gameplay are four hidden object sequences to find the key to each elemental book. The still paintings, while pretty, are a bit washed out on both the top screen and the touch screen, making it difficult to find each item. The fairy is available to point players in the right direction, but these sections feel like filler. There are also near-identical cards that require the player to spot the differences, which are short and relatively simple, but the small pictures on the card had us resort to pixel hunting and tapping the screen until we found something; these sequences aren't challenging so much as frustrating, and feel extraneous to the rest of the game.Although the colours seem a little washed out, the visuals are lovely and soft, evoking a fairy tale fantasy realm. The music and sound effects are quite soothing and peaceful, and the pay-off to a large combo or clearing a huge section of a level with "whoosh" and "ringing" sounds is surprisingly effective. The top screen is used as a map, while the bottom screen is where the action takes place. There is not much 3D implementation here, but it's not missed.Though 4 Elements is hampered by its filler hidden object/seek-and-find sequences, the puzzle gameplay is very fun and surprisingly involving. So while it's not the perfect puzzle game, players could certainly do worse. For a lengthy and well-crafted experience, 4 Elements is recommended; just be ready to do some pixel hunting in-between matching those jewels.

												Among many casual games that I've been playing, I took a particular liking towards this one, visiting it over and over again just to take my mind off something now and then. Is there anything extraordinary? Nah, not really. But it has a story at least.The Magic Land - yeah, this is the name of the realm that we are in. Creative I know, bear with me for the time - is in turmoil! The altars of the 4 Elements fell into ruin and the careful balance of nature is tipped off to result in catastrophes all over the place, so it is our casual gaming skills that shall save the Magic Land. With our trusted fairy companion - that girl is useful, I tell you - we are to unlock the books of 4 Elements and bring peace to the realm once again! For a casual game, it comes with a story and some lore about magical creatures. I must say that's a bonus.4 Elements is an entertaining, casual puzzle game that takes attention, quick-thinking and resourcefulness. Rules are very simple: your aim is to open a path way for the energy flow through the puzzle board labyrinth within a time limit, by matching as many possible same colored stones at a time. Your casual Match 3 game. It starts easy enough, and progresses to become 'what the heck I'm doing, I wonder???'. It has some HOG and “Find the Difference” scenes between chapters that are moronically hard: I couldn't decide whether they are a plus or a minus.The game itself is kinda addictive. You find yourself passing an hour or two, then realize that you've just lost that hour, which is the exact purpose of these games. Theme is really pretty, and the design is well above the average. I'd recommend it to whomever that looks for a fancy Bejeweled alternative with flashy gameplay and needs a game that doesn't use much brain activity rather than some attention span.Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												This is a different take on Match 3 genre. The story isn't anything spectacular (just read the About), but the games themselves are pretty good. Overall, the game isn't really difficult. Some of the later levels may require multiple tries to figure out the best strategy to make your way through.The gems do not require swapping. Instead, you draw a line through them to make a chain. The longer the chain, the bigger the explosion to wipe out surrounding gems, rocks, and other obstacles. The levels themselves are comprised of a long path that weaves its way to the destination. You must reach the destination before time runs out (the green bar on the right side). Sometimes, you must use power-ups to make your way through. The power-ups are charged when long chains are made. The longer the chain, the faster the power-up charges. The camera will stay still until you clear a path to allow the magic to flow further through the level.The game is divided into 4 parts (books), of which the following happens: A hidden object game preceeds a book in order to unlock it. Not only must you find the parts to objects, but then you must use the object to interact with something on the scene. Eventually the key is found to unlock the book. Once it is unlocked, there are 4 sets of 4 levels, each followed by a spot-the-difference game. In the higher levels, more differences must be found. Once the 4 sets are completed, it moves to the next book.The biggest problem with the game is the low resolution graphics. Even though it says it was made in 2008, they still could've used better graphics or at least provide a HD remaster. On 1920x1080, the grainy images for the hidden object and spot-the-differences mini-games made it somewhat difficult to complete. Putting it in windowed mode didn't help because then the images are just too small. A minor annoyance I had was the counter in the top-right corner of the screen. I couldn't figure out how to turn it off.Overall, the game is worth the cost for Match 3 type casual game fans. The level design makes it a bit different from the common single screen ones.---For more... My Reviews || My casual gaming...  Group | Curator Page

												4 Elements is an old tile matching game where you instead of moving tiles around to form links just point out to the game links that are already there. The game is not impressive or interesting and the fact that the individual levels are fairly lengthy means it does not even qualify as a decent timesink. Not a good game to buy.

												4 Elements is a simple, fun, relaxing game. The objective of each level is to clear the blocks, which destroys the path below them, which allows the water to progress. After a few boards, the game switches things up with some puzzles where you need to find the differences in two pictures or search for hidden objects. Many of these items/differences are extremely well hidden, basically blending into the backgrounds, which made that a bit of an annoyance. I had a few times where I just went click crazy all over the screen.There are A LOT of levels in this game. After a while I thought it would never end, so it does feel like it stretches out a bit too long. It's still fun and completely worth a play through, though I can't see me playing it again anytime soon. There are more addictive casual games out there.

												A 2008 3 match game developed by app designers Playrix (https://www.playrix.com/)There are a lot of OLD negative reviews based on the fact that the game crashes at start up etc. Also that there was no feedback from company which was surprising since they have over 450 employees. However since Mar 7 2017 there was an update and quite a few have remarked since then that game is now fixed and I myself had no problem with game working at all. I guess the moral of the story is check specifications before buying, and that Playrix really needs to work on its customer feedback, playing a more proactive role.Though the game is a 3 match I really found that it had a rather unique concept in comparison to other 3 matches I have played. Basic goal is to restore 4 elemental magic books, earth, fire, wind and water. To unlock a book you need a key, which you will find amongst an array of objects in a HOS. Once that is completed you are treated to 4 three match games followed by a relatively easy spot the difference this will give you a short read about the magic of a mythical character such as a faerie, a water turtle, a  unicorn or something of the like. Repeat this procedure three times in total and you will unlock all the locks to one of the four books and may then proceed to the next one to repeat the process until you have finished all 65 levels or thereabout levels, learnt all about the magical inhabitants of this mythical world and then rainbows will appear over the Kingdom, the end.The first two books are so easy thanks to the large generous amount of time allocated to the completion of each level that you could probably watch grass grow between each match up and still successfully complete each level. The last two books on the other hand are so strapped for time you'll probably have to go back to the doctor’s tomo and get yourself a heavier prescription. For instance the last level took me around 16 minutes and I was flying around the map like I was a cat in a room full of rocking chairs.The main objective of the 3 match puzzles is to get a fluid from the start point to the altar, its exit goal. Unfortunately dirt, blocks and ice often prevent your path. By matching 3 or more gems in a horizontal or vertical fashion will remove the dirt. Making a 5 match adjacent to ice will cause an explosion that will move that obstacle and as for the cement blocks you will have to locate an explosive spear and let the liquid meet that for the spear to shoot off and make contact with another spear or the cement block and obliterate that obstacle. The journey can be quite long as you make the liquid traverse through tight narrow passages and patterned chasms. You have some power ups also at your disposal depending on which colour gems you match up. A spade will unlock one block of dirt (green gem), a bomb can take out the ice and rocks (red gem), a switch will change the position of a pair of gems of your choosing (yellow gem) and random will randomise the gem layout again when you get limited in good options (blue gem).The game is unique not only for its mechanics, it's board fancy grandiose lay out, but also thanks to its background animations, such as an assortment of fish swimming around in a gigantic aqua world or the waterfalls that emit from the mouth of the altar when your fluid reaches them. Not to mention the barrage of explosions that can occur when you come across a cluster of explosive spears like as if you’re watching a Michael Bay Movie about 3 match extremists.In final the first two books are really boring they take too long explaining the game, the last two books are worthy of a gamer's attention. Hopefully they will continue with this idea looking into 4 other magical elements like Xanox, Mushroom, Moonshine and Testosterone.

You may need to find an object to uncover a button which opens a chest which has part of another object inside - and so on. Once you've solved the puzzle and opened the book, you are faced with the task of collecting four 'cards' featuring a different mythical creature or race. You do this by playing two different puzzles - a series of 'spot the difference' games, and the main bulk of the game: a series of four puzzles whereby you must direct the flow of 'magic' to a given point by destroying groups of gems. The plot is all by-the-by if you just want to play the puzzles, which is great, because the storytelling isn't exactly stellar. 												I wanted to wait until I completed this game to sing its praises and I'm glad that I did.  They saved the best two stages in the game for last.  (Good on you, you cheeky buggers.)'4 Elements' would make a charming addition to any puzzle-lover's collection as well as those with a taste for casual games.  With most stages taking no more than five minutes each, the ability to save and quit at any given time, even in the middle of a puzzle and continue at your convenience, the creators have clearly put a great deal of thought into smoothing out not only the mechanics of the game, but the way it is presented to you, the player.'The baby's crying?  Dinner is ready?  Don't worry--we'll leave this just as you left it.'Everything within this simple puzzle title is polished to perfection:The artwork and related 'find the difference' mini-games are masterpieces on their own, especially in the way that they are assembled according to your progression.  Every click of a button results in a harmonious tap or chime, rewarding your headway with a rush of flowing water or wisp of wind, weaving an encouraging musical atmosphere as you restore the world around you.  The stages themselves have a smooth difficulty curve as well, challenging enough to feel rewarding and encourage creative strategies without leading you to frustration.A brilliant puzzle game and highly recommended.  I look forward to a sequel.

												This is a pleasant match-three puzzle game with some good art and polish, and it's not too long.In this game, you have to dig through a bunch of dirt so that some liquid can flow to the end of the level. You dig by eliminating tiles on top of the dirt. The camera scrolls on its own as it follows the liquid, and you can't scroll back to earlier parts of the level, so you have to deal with only what you see on the screen. Sometimes the randomness will deal a bad hand, but you can get out of trouble with planning and clever use of powerups.I admit, I first thought it was a bit easy and simplistic for my tastes -- there are only four colors to match, and the powerups were a bit too powerful. About halfway through the game, I realized the main enemy was the timer, and it could put up a good fight. Later levels got fast and frantic as I had to dig through huge levels in only a few minutes, and the final few levels were quite a satisfying challenge.Overall, it was pretty good! It seems like something straight out of the golden age of PopCap. If you have fond memories of Zuma, Bejeweled, Chuzzle, Bookworm, and the like, you might find this very enjoyable. For achievement hunters, this is a no-brainer. Get it on sale for an easy 5-7 hour perfect game.

												Yet another "match 3"-like game. Though, this time, no tile to move but tiles to select, starting at 3 that have at least one border in common. The more you link, the better. At 5 linked (or more) an explosion happens, clearing more background and tiles. Some more options can be set during the game (bomb, swap tile, etc.), provided you filled them up first. Throught the four books, representing the elements, there are four "find the differences" mini games per book, and one other "find the object" mini game per book. That's the basic of gameplay. Design wise, it's a very pleasant trip. The graphics are beautiful and music is relaxing. "4 Elements" starts easy but quickly becomes challenging. Near the end, it leans towards the very difficult. Around the last levels (amongst 66) the automated camera may show a part of the screen that isn't very useful. And that's  about the only issue I've found.

												Mini games and colour maching the game.introduction:To start out with, you are introduced to the story, wich involve the elements running amok in a magical world. We are told to restore peace to each element; earth, wind, fire, and water. On the menu screen we can see all the levls representet by books and gems, and we get an idea of how long this game is going to take.Therefore I felt the introduction to be really boring. It shows the whole game from the get go, and there are no surprises along the way. Then again for a game like this, you would not expect much more than that. Gamplay:The gamepaly is split up into 3 diffrent games, where one acts as the main game, while the others are mini-games. The main game is very simple, match coloured blocks in a chain, in order to make sand dissaper. When the sand is gone, the water you need to get to the end of the stage can continue to flow. After you let the water flow to the end, you win the level.The levels have diffrent obsticles along the way that can block the way to completion, these items is for eksample rocks. The levels are getting harder along the way, but you also unlock power-ups, that will help you to remove opsticles and reach the goal. The power-ups fells really overpowered, and can easily make the game a win for you, nearly every single time. This was a huge letdown for me, since I never really felt challenged. The powerups can be things like changing around blocks and blowing up paths. The two mini games are done, in order to unlock new levels. The first one is a "spot the diffrence" game, where you click a place on a picture, to spot the flaw on the other picture. The other part is a "find the objects" game, where you must spot things hidding in the background. All the games are controlled by simple mouse-clicking., and it fells rather slow and boring now and again. The overall games are not boring as such, but it quikly get`s repetative.Charecters:Well there are only two charecters in this game, and they both have no persanality. This game is clearly not story driven, but in my opinion, they did not need to include these charecters to complete a already unnesesary story. The charecters are a wizard, which we never see after the starting scren, and a fariy which guides you throughout the game. There is not much to say to this part, so let`s move on.Visuels:The game looks kinda ok, but I really did not exspect anything brillaint to be honest. The overall visuesl in-game are accually pretty fluid, and looks fine. But when you do anything outside the main game, the grafics fells weaker and more bluery. It`s hard to explain, but I felt there was something off.Sound:The music is acually ok in this game. I fellt it was a nice thing to include, and the diffrent themes are acually not that bad. Other then that, there are not much to say to the sounds other than the start theme will blast your speakers out, it is so loud!Story:So the story is pretty basic as said, clear all levels to controle all elements. The boring part is that the sory really has no twists and turns, instead it fells like it only is there to give you a reason to why there is 4 main levels. The other mini-games really has some cool story. Not so much the hidden object part. But when you complete the spot the diffrence game. You see the real picture, and get`s the lore of the charecter on it. This was some intresting reading, and felt like a nice inclusion to the game, and the lore of the establist world. But this is also where I don't really understand why they would create so mutch lore to a matching game. it feels really unessesary. Conclusion:The game is far from a masterpice, and it really is just another time killer game. This dose not mean I dislike the game at all, I am just saying you can find better games of this type out there. I completed the story and it really is just a congratiolation screen and nothing more. But if you are looking for a simple game to sit down and play, this one could be a nice choice.

												TL;DR: This game is the definition of shovelware-made-for-mobile-hidden-object-game trash. And if youre looking for a Match-3 RPG DO NOT look here!Ok, so the tags are misleading. This is mostly a fantasy themed HOG (Hidden Object game), not a match 3 RPG like Puzzle Quest.  It has a tiny "match 3" component, if you can call it that. You do that a few times in each book before going back to the "find pieces of items HOG" to get the new key to open a new book.Theres no choice, no choosing of puzzles, and a very weak fantasy plot with an annoying fairy that constantly flits around the screen. Its like its badly built for 5 year olds. If you like HOGs (oh god, why??) theres WAY better ones out there. And if you like Match 3 RPGs theres way way better ones. This MAY entertain a 6 year old. 												This is not an exceptionally long game. You can beat it and earn all the achievements in rather short order (my play time includes needing to start over again roughly halfway through due to computer issues). Yet, it's well worth getting on sale. Basically, it's a match-three game in which you attempt to create a path for yourself through each level, using power-ups to assist you as needed. Longer chain matches lead to ever bigger explosions, making your work easier and faster. There are some fun twists to some of the levels, each world has its own feel to it, and it really is rather relaxing. To be honest, there were very few levels in the game that I was not able to beat the first time without running out of time, and none that took me more than two tries, so the degree of challenge might not be quite enough for some, but I view it as a positive. While beating the game is faster that way, it is also rendered largely free of the frustration that comes with countless deaths on the same level. Overall, if you like casual/match 3 games at all, then this is one to check out.It does seem fair to warn you of some negatives before you do so though. First, and most annoying, while there are hidden object and spot the difference style mini-games that you play at regular intervals to advance further in the game, the images are in rather low resolution, making what you're meant to spot rather difficult to see much of the time. Fortunately, there's a hint feature and no time limit, nor is there any penalty for random clicking, so when you can't see something these levels are still easily beatable. Also, as a fairly unimportant negative to the game, all the story elements that go along with the gameplay are not exactly going to fill you with excitement, if you care about such things in this kind of game. At least you'll now be a bit aware of what to expect though.

Summary:- 4 "click on everything to find the hidden object pixels" puzzles- 64 "match same gem types to form a path" levels- 16 "find the pixel differences" puzzles- nicely done graphics and animations- for the currently discounted 0.79c ... that's less than a cent per feature.Can't really go wrong there, and it kept me (and my 2yr old niece) entertained for a good number of hours. I'd say it's a good buy even at the regular price.A few points that could use improvement (perhaps in a v2):- No real replayability. Once you've solved level 64, and perhaps hunted down the missing achievements, there's no reason to fire up the game anymore.Suggestions: let the game keep track of your individual level solution times or scores, to add an incentive to replay for better scores. Additionally, the game really should offer a built-in way to replay specific previously completed levels. As it is now, if you like certain levels and wish to revisit them, the game forces you to play all previous levels first to get to the ones you actually wished to replay, or... you have to edit the savegame xml. Ugh.A slightly more ambitious suggestion: a level design or mod tool would extend the lifetime of this game considerably.- No graphics/resolution options. Well, there is exactly one: fullscreen y/n. Fullscreen appears to be fixed at 800x600 regardless of screen native size, and windowed it cannot be resized either. Trying to find the hidden pixels of a tiny 800x600 window on a full HD (or more!) screen becomes very tiring for the eyes.It really should not need to be said that graphics and resolution options are a must for PC games. - Very frequent, randomly timed freezing. The game very regularly -every few minutes on average, but sometimes several times a minute- freezes up while playing a level, and becomes completely unresponsive for 1-5 seconds at a time. Very annoying!I haven't been able to figure out a pattern in this. Sometimes it seemed to happen when the cursor moved to/over the edge of the window. Other times it seemed timed with one of the animations onscreen. Browser, Steam client, notepad, task manager, Windows menu all respond fluently at the time the game freezes up, so it is very clearly just the game window. The only actual bug I've encountered, but it's an annoying one.End verdict: Annoyances aside, it's a good game for a good price if you like this sort of casual puzzles. Very kid friendly too (my 2yr old niece approves).

You start at one point and need to reach another point within allocated time. There are 4 power ups which help you on the way. These power ups charge as you match more of the same colored gems. This is a good game to play when waiting for matchmade/MOBA games.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												I really liked this game... on my first playthrough.Puzzles include 4 FROG (fractured object) screens, 16 spot-the-difference screens, and 64 match-3 levels.  The main match-3 levels are different from any other genre game I have played.  I was expecting a classic Bejeweled-style game, but instead of swapping tiles or sliding rows, you form chains by clicking and dragging a path through adjacent matching symbols.  The paths do not have to form a straight line, you can zig-zag any direction except diagonally (for all the explanation the game gives, they never actually tell you this).  As the game progresses, you will encounter obstacles such as ice, immovable blocks, narrow passages, and rocks; however, you will also gain access to rechargeable tools that help you overcome these obstacles.  There is a timer, but chances are you will not need to worry about it until 3/4 of the way through the game, and even if you fail you just restart the level with no penalties.  The levels are increasingly challenging, but never frustrating or boring.  In fact, I found I enjoyed the later levels more because they forced you to use a bit of strategy to complete.  I thought it was a nice touch that each of the four elements have a slightly different level aesthetic, which helps keep the levels feeling fresh.As great as the gameplay was, though, there are things that destroy the replay value:- The story is cheesy.  Although, that's to be expected for this genre.- The chatty fairy.  She was fine for the first playthrough, providing necessary instructions and tips to help you learn and understand the game.  Subsequent playthroughs, though, are a different story - her dialogue cannot be skipped or turned off, so you will have to suffer through "Pop-Ups: The Game" every single time.  This is annoying if you just want to sit down and replay a few levels casually.- There is no option to select your starting level.  Whether you want to challenge yourself by replaying a tricky stage, or whether you are just trying to go for a specific achievement, your only choices are to continue from your last autosave or to completely start over.  Again, this is fine for the first playthrough, but an unlockable freeplay mode would have been appreciated.- The achievements are a bear to get.  It took me 1.5 playthroughs to get "Overachiever" because it is partially luck-dependent, and "Quick as a Flash" took 11 angry hours: The first FROG screen does not count toward the achievement because the fairy's dialogue and tutorial eat up so much of your time, so you are left with only three chances per game to earn it (the FROGs for the fire key, the air key, and the water key).  Basically, this means you will need to play through 16 match-3 levels and 4 spot-the-difference puzzles before you even reach the first applicable fractured object screen, and you will be continuously forced to deal with the fairy's "helpfulness."  If you miss the 90-second timeframe on the fire key puzzle, there is no way to just try it again because the game autosaves just AFTER you complete it.  You will either need to restart the game, or hope that you have better luck with the air key.  Regardless, you are looking at another 16 levels and 4 puzzles before getting a second opportunity to win this achievement.  If there had been either a freeplay mode, or a way to turn off the fairy, I might have given this game a 9.5/10 because the gameplay is solid, and it would have been incredibly replayable.  As is, though, I would have to give it a 6.5/10.

												I really liked this game... on my first playthrough.Puzzles include 4 FROG (fractured object) screens, 16 spot-the-difference screens, and 64 match-3 levels.  The main match-3 levels are different from any other genre game I have played.  I was expecting a classic Bejeweled-style game, but instead of swapping tiles or sliding rows, you form chains by clicking and dragging a path through adjacent matching symbols.  The paths do not have to form a straight line, you can zig-zag any direction except diagonally (for all the explanation the game gives, they never actually tell you this).  As the game progresses, you will encounter obstacles such as ice, immovable blocks, narrow passages, and rocks; however, you will also gain access to rechargeable tools that help you overcome these obstacles.  There is a timer, but chances are you will not need to worry about it until 3/4 of the way through the game, and even if you fail you just restart the level with no penalties.  The levels are increasingly challenging, but never frustrating or boring.  In fact, I found I enjoyed the later levels more because they forced you to use a bit of strategy to complete.  I thought it was a nice touch that each of the four elements have a slightly different level aesthetic, which helps keep the levels feeling fresh.As great as the gameplay was, though, there are things that destroy the replay value:- The story is cheesy.  Although, that's to be expected for this genre.- The chatty fairy.  She was fine for the first playthrough, providing necessary instructions and tips to help you learn and understand the game.  Subsequent playthroughs, though, are a different story - her dialogue cannot be skipped or turned off, so you will have to suffer through "Pop-Ups: The Game" every single time.  This is annoying if you just want to sit down and replay a few levels casually.- There is no option to select your starting level.  Whether you want to challenge yourself by replaying a tricky stage, or whether you are just trying to go for a specific achievement, your only choices are to continue from your last autosave or to completely start over.  Again, this is fine for the first playthrough, but an unlockable freeplay mode would have been appreciated.- The achievements are a bear to get.  It took me 1.5 playthroughs to get "Overachiever" because it is partially luck-dependent, and "Quick as a Flash" took 11 angry hours: The first FROG screen does not count toward the achievement because the fairy's dialogue and tutorial eat up so much of your time, so you are left with only three chances per game to earn it (the FROGs for the fire key, the air key, and the water key).  Basically, this means you will need to play through 16 match-3 levels and 4 spot-the-difference puzzles before you even reach the first applicable fractured object screen, and you will be continuously forced to deal with the fairy's "helpfulness."  If you miss the 90-second timeframe on the fire key puzzle, there is no way to just try it again because the game autosaves just AFTER you complete it.  You will either need to restart the game, or hope that you have better luck with the air key.  Regardless, you are looking at another 16 levels and 4 puzzles before getting a second opportunity to win this achievement.  If there had been either a freeplay mode, or a way to turn off the fairy, I might have given this game a 9.5/10 because the gameplay is solid, and it would have been incredibly replayable.  As is, though, I would have to give it a 6.5/10.

												I'm beginning to agree with all the Steam reviewers who think we need to have a "neutral" button for reviews. While I enjoyed my time with 4 Elements, I can't *strongly* recommend it, but if you like match-3 type games and find it on sale (I got it while it was only 99 cents), then there are probably worse ways to spend your time and money. The game also features Hidden Object and Find the Differences scenes, but the (very) main focus are the match-3 puzzle scenes in which you clear a path for a flow of energy to make it to a goal by chaining together three or more objects of the same color in a row. The more objects you chain up, the bigger an explosion it makes, causing the energy to flow farther. It's kinda fun and addicting, especially to scout the screen for the largest possible chain to make and to watch the ensuing chaos as it explodes and takes out the surroundings, sometimes even setting off arrows that travel across the screen and blow away even more crap.The game is long, but rather easy. The last few levels introduce some new gimmicks that make them harder, such as one where the screen auto-scrolls and you have to manically keep forming chains so that the energy flow keeps up with it. But it seems like more of this kind of thing was needed. I know, welcome to Casual Gaming, right? While I replayed the game just enough to get the achievements, I wouldn't want to go all the way through it again right away because it can get monotonous.Finally, the richness of the story is a bit overstated in this game's description. Mostly it's in the form of cards you get after doing the "find the differences" scenes, which have a picture of a fantasy animal, knight, or humanoid race on it with a description of them. The hand-drawn graphics are beautiful, but the style sometimes makes it difficult to tell where the differences are or the hidden objects are.In short, if you like this type of game and it's on sale, go for it. If not, it's a safe skip.Rating: 3/5
